Ken,

I just want to add to the above that this was my first exposure to
ob=
jective-less search, and in spite of my concerns I found the paper
thought-=
provoking and well-written over all.

Daniel

On Fri, Apr 1, 2011 at 10:06 =
PM, Daniel Tuohy <danielr2e@...> wrote:

> Ken,
>
> First off, I'll s=
ay that what I take as the central point, that EAs can
> miss critical inte=
rmediate objectives because they are awkwardly placed on
> the fitness land=
scape, is a good one.  However, I have some concerns about
> the experiment=
al design in this paper:
>
> (1) You appear to be manipulating two variable=
s at once.  (a) whether the
> EA has an objective and (b) whether there is =
a human in the loop.  Surely
> you have to pick only one at a time and cont=
rol for everything else, right?
>
>
> (2) Furthermore, if it's IGA v. GA an=
d 'interestingness' is the evaluation
> criteria, that ain't a fair fight. =
 Why should I believe there is more to it
> than that?
>
> (3) How do we kn=
ow that intermediate objectives are in any way significant
> to discovering=
 interesting pictures in Picbreeder?  I have a sneaking
> suspicion that to=
tally random search, followed by focused objective based
> search when some=
thing 'pops' might be just as effective, and that the
> 'intermediate objec=
tives', while certainly necessary to find a *particular
> * image, are not =
very helpful in general to finding interesting images.
>  If so, this is no=
 chink in the armor of objective based search.  I suppose
> without interme=
diate objectives there can be no exaptation, but does that
> matter?  What =
percentage of evolved features in biological organisms have
> any exaptatio=
n at all in their history?
>
> (4) Finally - and this is the big one - one =
of the deadly sins of Science
> is claiming a result as the objective a pos=
teriori, a point which eludes
> even some very famous scientists.  It's wha=
t allows publications like this<http://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2010/11/f=
eeling-the-future-is-precognition-possible/>, which
> 'prove' psychic pheno=
mena by mining data for 'statistically significant'
> results.  The problem=
 is, a result isn't significant unless you were
> specifically attempting t=
o confirm it when the experiment was designed (i.e.
> always follow up expl=
oratory experiment with a confirmatory experiment!).  I
> heartily endorse =
exploring for/marvelling at results you weren't initially
> looking for, bu=
t one should never use such results as the basis for any sort
> of comparis=
on.  In the case of the eye experiment, who cares if the GA
> couldn't evol=
ve the eye?  The IGA can't either, and the fact that it already
> did is im=
material!  I could be persuaded that the IGA is better at evolving
> intere=
sting images, but I do not believe it's any better at evolving the
> 'eye' =
(or 'dolphin', or 'apple').  In fact, I would bet that's it's *worse
> * at=
 evolving those specific images, intermediate objectives
> notwithstanding.=

>
> Anyway, though I have a lot of doubts about this particular paper, I r=
eally
> appreciate these sorts of research directions.  Keep up the good wo=
rk!
>
> Daniel
>
> On Fri, Apr 1, 2011 at 7:09 PM, Ken <kstanley@....=
edu> wrote:
>
>>
>>
>> Brian Woolley and I are pleased to announce our new =
paper to appear at
>> GECCO, "On the Deleterious Effects of A Priori Object=
ives on Evolution and
>> Representation." You can get it here:
>>
>> http:/=
/eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/woolley_gecco11.pdf
>>
>> Abstract:
>> http://eple=
x.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2011/woolley.gecco11.html
>>
>> As some of you ha=
ve been following through our articles on novelty search
>> and my keynote =
talk on "Searching Without Objectives," our research group
>> has been ques=
tioning the role of objectives in evolution and machine
>> learning. Howeve=
r, much of this focus has been on exploring alternative
>> paradigms such a=
s novelty search. In contrast, this new paper aims to expose
>> directly so=
me of the most serious problems with objective-based search
>> itself, both=
 practically and philosophically.
>>
>> The message is not only that object=
ives may not be the best way to drive
>> evolution. Perhaps deeper than tha=
t, the results suggest that the usual way
>> we evaluate our algorithms, i.=
e. by giving them a task and seeing how
>> reliably they can solve it, may =
be flawed in the sense that it may not
>> actually be accurately measuring =
the real potential of such algorithms. We
>> probably should rethink whethe=
r demanding the same result over and over
>> again with 100% reliability is=
 really a good way to ascertain the potential
>> an evolutionary algorithm.=
 The paper gives the full story.
>>
>> ken
>>
>>  
>>
>
>

--bcaec51b1eadaca86f049fe69a5e

Ken,<div><br></div><div>I just want to add to the above that this was my fi=
rst exposure to objective-less search, and in spite of my concerns I found =
the paper thought-provoking and well-written over all. =A0</div><div><br></=
div>

<div>Daniel<br><br><div class=3D"gmail_quote">On Fri, Apr 1, 2011 at =
10:06 PM, Daniel Tuohy <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:danielr2e@gm=
ail.com">danielr2e@...</a>></span> wrote:<br><blockquote class=3D"=
gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc solid;padding-=
left:1ex;">

Ken,=A0<div><br></div><div>First off, I'll say that what I=
 take as the central point,=A0that EAs can miss critical intermediate objec=
tives because they are awkwardly placed on the fitness landscape, is a good=
 one. =A0However, I have some concerns about the experimental design in thi=
s paper:</div>


<div><br></div><div>(1) You appear to be manipulating two =
variables at once. =A0(a) whether the EA has an objective and (b) whether t=
here is a human in the loop. =A0Surely you have to pick only one at a time =
and control for everything else, right? =A0</div>


<div><br></div><div>(2)=
 Furthermore, if it's IGA v. GA and 'interestingness' is the ev=
aluation criteria, that ain't a fair fight. =A0Why should I believe the=
re is more to it than that?</div><div><br></div><div>


(3)=A0How do we kno=
w that intermediate objectives are in any way significant to discovering in=
teresting pictures in Picbreeder? =A0I have a sneaking suspicion that total=
ly random search, followed by focused objective based search when something=
 'pops' might be just as effective, and that the 'intermediate =
objectives', while certainly necessary to find a <i>particular</i> imag=
e, are not very helpful in general to finding interesting images. =A0If so,=
 this is no chink in the armor of objective based search. =A0I suppose with=
out intermediate objectives there can be no exaptation, but does that matte=
r? =A0What percentage of evolved features in biological organisms have any =
exaptation at all in their history?</div>


<div><br></div><div>(4) Finally=
 - and this is the big one - one of the deadly sins of Science is claiming =
a result as the objective a posteriori, a point which eludes even some very=
 famous scientists. =A0It's what allows publications like <a href=3D"ht=
tp://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2010/11/feeling-the-future-is-precognition-=
possible/" target=3D"_blank">this</a>,=A0which 'prove' psychic phen=
omena by mining data for 'statistically significant' results. =A0Th=
e problem is, a result isn't significant unless you were specifically a=
ttempting to confirm it when the experiment was designed (i.e. always follo=
w up exploratory experiment with a confirmatory experiment!). =A0I heartily=
 endorse exploring for/marvelling at results you weren't initially look=
ing for, but one should never use such results as the basis for any sort of=
 comparison. =A0In the case of the eye experiment, who cares if the GA coul=
dn't evolve the eye? =A0The IGA can't either, and the fact that it =
already did is immaterial! =A0I could be persuaded that the IGA is better a=
t evolving interesting images, but I do not believe it's any better at =
evolving the 'eye' (or 'dolphin', or 'apple'). =A0I=
n fact, I would bet that's it's <i>worse</i> at evolving those spec=
ific images, intermediate objectives notwithstanding.</div>


<div><br></di=
v><div>Anyway, though I have a lot of doubts about this particular paper, I=
 really appreciate these sorts of research directions. =A0Keep up the good =
work!</div><div><br></div><font color=3D"#888888"><div>Daniel</div>

</font=
><div><div></div><div class=3D"h5"><div><br><div class=3D"gmail_quote">

Fri, Apr 1, 2011 at 7:09 PM, Ken <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:ks=
tanley@..." target=3D"_blank">kstanley@...</a>></spa=
n> wrote:<br><blockquote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;b=
order-left:1px #ccc solid;padding-left:1ex">
















<div style=3D"=
background-color:#fff">
<span>=A0</span>


<div>
  <div>


    <div>
      =

      
      <p>Brian Woolley and I are pleased to announce our new paper =
to appear at GECCO, "On the Deleterious Effects of A Priori Objectives=
 on Evolution and Representation."  You can get it here:<br>
<br>
<a h=
ref=3D"http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/woolley_gecco11.pdf" target=3D"_blank=
">http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/woolley_gecco11.pdf</a><br>
<br>
Abstract:=
 <br>
<a href=3D"http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2011/woolley.gecco11.=
html" target=3D"_blank">http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2011/woolley.g=
ecco11.html</a><br>
<br>
As some of you have been following through our art=
icles on novelty search and my keynote talk on "Searching Without Obje=
ctives," our research group has been questioning the role of objective=
s in evolution and machine learning.  However, much of this focus has been =
on exploring alternative paradigms such as novelty search.  In contrast, th=
is new paper aims to expose directly some of the most serious problems with=
 objective-based search itself, both practically and philosophically.<br>

=


<br>
The message is not only that objectives may not be the best way to d=
rive evolution.  Perhaps deeper than that, the results suggest that the usu=
al way we evaluate our algorithms, i.e. by giving them a task and seeing ho=
w reliably they can solve it, may be flawed in the sense that it may not ac=
tually be accurately measuring the real potential of such algorithms.  We p=
robably should rethink whether demanding the same result over and over agai=
n with 100% reliability is really a good way to ascertain the potential an =
evolutionary algorithm.  The paper gives the full story.<br>



<br>
ken<br=
>
<br>
</p>

    </div>
     

    
    <div style=3D"color:#fff;min-height=
:0"></div>


</div>
